paragraphs.title: Introduction
paragraphs.text:
%md

# Introduction


Typically there're 3 essential steps for building one flink job. And each step has its favorite tools.

* Define source/sink (SQL DDL)
* Define data flow (Table Api / SQL)
* Implement business logic (UDF)

This tutorial demonstrates how to build one typical flinkjob  via these 3 steps and their favorite tools.
In this demo, we will do real time analysis of cdn access data. First we read cdn access log from kafka queue and do some processing and aggregation, then write the result to mysql database. We use this [docker](https://zeppelin-kafka-connect-datagen.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) to create kafka cluster and source data. You need to prepare mysql database by yourself. 

* Make sure you add the following ip host name mapping to your hosts file, otherwise you may not be able to connect to the kafka cluster in docker

```
127.0.0.1   broker
```

Use the following command to generate the sample data.

```
curl -X POST http://localhost:8083/connectors \
-H 'Content-Type:application/json' \
-H 'Accept:application/json' \
-d @cdn.source.datagen.json
```

msg.data:
Introduction

Typically there’re 3 essential steps for building one flink job. And each step has its favorite tools.

  • Define source/sink (SQL DDL)
  • Define data flow (Table Api / SQL)
  • Implement business logic (UDF)

This tutorial demonstrates how to build one typical flinkjob via these 3 steps and their favorite tools.
In this demo, we will do real time analysis of cdn access data. First we read cdn access log from kafka queue and do some processing and aggregation, then write the result to mysql database. We use this docker to create kafka cluster and source data. You need to prepare mysql database by yourself.

  • Make sure you add the following ip host name mapping to your hosts file, otherwise you may not be able to connect to the kafka cluster in docker
127.0.0.1   broker

Use the following command to generate the sample data.

curl -X POST http://localhost:8083/connectors \
-H 'Content-Type:application/json' \
-H 'Accept:application/json' \
-d @cdn.source.datagen.json

paragraphs.title: Configuration
paragraphs.text:
%flink.conf

# This example use kafka as source and mysql as sink, so you need to specify flink kafka connector and flink jdbc connector first.

flink.execution.packages	org.apache.flink:flink-connector-kafka_2.11:1.10.0,org.apache.flink:flink-connector-kafka-base_2.11:1.10.0,org.apache.flink:flink-json:1.10.0,org.apache.flink:flink-jdbc_2.11:1.10.0,mysql:mysql-connector-java:5.1.38

# Set taskmanager.memory.segment-size to be the smallest value just for this demo, otherwise you will see the result change after a long time due to the buffer in upstream vertex.
taskmanager.memory.segment-size 4k

paragraphs.title: Define source table
paragraphs.text:
%flink.ssql

DROP table if exists cdn_access_log;

CREATE TABLE cdn_access_log (
 uuid VARCHAR,
 client_ip VARCHAR,
 request_time BIGINT,
 response_size BIGINT,
 uri VARCHAR,
 event_ts BIGINT
) WITH (
 'connector.type' = 'kafka',
 'connector.version' = 'universal',
 'connector.topic' = 'cdn_events',
 'connector.properties.zookeeper.connect' = 'localhost:2181',
 'connector.properties.bootstrap.servers' = 'localhost:9092',
 'connector.properties.group.id' = 'testGroup',
 'format.type' = 'json',
 'connector.startup-mode' = 'earliest-offset',
 'update-mode' = 'append'
)

paragraphs.title: Define sink table
paragraphs.text:
%flink.ssql

DROP table if exists cdn_access_statistic;

-- Please create this mysql table first in your mysql instance. Flink won't create mysql table for you.

CREATE TABLE cdn_access_statistic (
 province VARCHAR,
 access_count BIGINT,
 total_download BIGINT,
 download_speed DOUBLE
) WITH (
 'connector.type' = 'jdbc',
 'connector.url' = 'jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/flink_cdn',
 'connector.table' = 'cdn_access_statistic',
 'connector.username' = 'root',
 'connector.password' = '123456',
 'connector.write.flush.interval' = '1s'
)

paragraphs.title: PyFlink UDF
paragraphs.text:
%flink.ipyflink

import re
import json
from pyflink.table import DataTypes
from pyflink.table.udf import udf
from urllib.parse import quote_plus
from urllib.request import urlopen

# This UDF is to convert ip address to country. Here we simply the logic just for demo purpose.

@udf(input_types=[DataTypes.STRING()], result_type=DataTypes.STRING())
def ip_to_country(ip):

    countries = ['USA', 'China', 'Japan', 'South Korea', 'France', 'Germany', 'Italy', 'Russia', 'Canada']
    last_dot = ip.rfind('.')
    country_index = int(ip[(last_dot+1) :]) % len(countries)
    return countries[country_index]


st_env.register_function("ip_to_country", ip_to_country)

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: PyFlink Table Api
paragraphs.text:
%flink.ipyflink

t = st_env.from_path("cdn_access_log")\
   .select("uuid, "
           "ip_to_country(client_ip) as country, " 
           "response_size, request_time")\
  .group_by("country")\
  .select(
          "country, count(uuid) as access_count, " 
          "sum(response_size) as total_download,  " 
          "sum(response_size) * 1.0 / sum(request_time) as download_speed")
   #.insert_into("cdn_access_statistic")

# z.show will display the result in zeppelin front end in table format, you can uncomment the above insert statement and the below st_env.execute in order to write the data to mysql table.    
z.show(t, stream_type="update")
#st_env.execute("pyflink_cdn_access_job")

paragraphs.title: Flink Sql
paragraphs.text:
%flink.ssql

insert into cdn_access_statistic
select ip_to_country(client_ip) as country, 
       count(uuid) as access_count, 
       sum(response_size) as total_download ,
       sum(response_size) * 1.0 / sum(request_time) as download_speed
from cdn_access_log
  group by ip_to_country(client_ip)

%md

# Query sink table via jdbc interpreter

You can also query the sink table (mysql) directly via jdbc interpreter. Here I will create a jdbc interpreter named `mysql` and use it to query the sink table. Regarding how to connect mysql in Zeppelin, refer this [link](http://zeppelin.apache.org/docs/0.9.0-preview1/interpreter/jdbc.html#mysql)
